ENGL 153.course_description: An introduction to the craft of poetry, fiction, and creative nonfiction, including reading as a writer. No prior writing experience required.

ENGL 154.course_description: An exploration of the elements of narrative technique. No prior experience in fiction writing is assumed. Investigates characterization, plot, setting, scene, detail, and point of view. This course does not count toward the English major with a creative writing emphasis.

ENGL 155.course_description: An exploration of the practice of writing poetry. No prior experience in poetry writing is assumed. Investigates a variety of approaches to the composition of a poem and such elements of poetry as image, rhythm, line, sound, pattern, and structure. This course does not count toward the English major with a creative writing emphasis.

ENGL 156.course_name: Creative Writing for Beginners: Additional Genres
ENGL 156.course_description: An exploration of and practice with the elements of a creative writing genre such as Satire, Graphic Novel or Memoir, or Screenwriting. May be repeated for additional credit.

ENGL 158.course_description: An introduction to the art of writing the contemporary literary essay. Includes work on style, structure, audience, and critical thinking and reading in essays by a broad range of writers. Topics may include humor, commentary, opinion, personal observation, autobiography, argument, social criticism, occasional essay.

ENGL 195.course_description: A course offered in response to student and instructor interest. Topics are not generally covered in the regular course listings. Course may be taken multiple times if topics are different.

ENGL 213.course_description: This course will introduce students to prominent theories and practices in the study of rhetoric and writing. Students will learn about the history of rhetoric, the role of writing instruction in colleges and universities, and the methodologies used to create new knowledge within this field of study.

ENGL 214.course_description: A course designed to further the student’s ability to write the types of expository prose appropriate to business, business administration, and technical fields.

ENGL 222.course_description: This course presents a cumulative study of the conventions governing spoken and written American Standard English. It is designed to model creative learning strategies that are easily adaptable for future teachers, and to develop editing and writing skills in addition to mechanical competence. The workshop will help you become a better speaker, teacher, writer - indeed, a more competent professional in whatever field you choose. You will learn to identify and correct the most common usage errors, and to explore ways of helping others move beyond them.

ENGL 240.course_description: A course that teaches practical, applicable, real-world writing skills and forms. The course may focus on grant writing, science writing, technical writing, writing for non-profits, multimodal composing, writing for the web, blogging and digital writing, writing in the public sphere, advanced argument, rhetorical studies, literacy studies, or other composition studies, individually or in combination. Intended particularly for the general liberal arts student and/or English elective credits. May be repeated for additional credit in a different focus area.

ENGL 254.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of fiction. Includes extensive reading in contemporary fiction. Students revise and complete a series of short works or one longer work.

ENGL 255.course_description: An introduction to the practice of writing poetry. Includes a variety of approaches to the composition of a poem as well as the elements of poetry: image, rhythm, line, sound, pattern, form, and structure.

ENGL 256.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of a creative writing genre such as the Novel, Graphic Fiction, Translation, or Screenwriting. May be repeated for additional credit.

ENGL 258.course_description: An introduction to the art of writing the contemporary literary essay. Includes work on style, structure, audience, and critical thinking and reading in essays by a broad range of writers. Topics may include humor, commentary, opinion, personal observation, autobiography, argument, social criticism, occasional essay.

ENGL 295.course_description: A topic in literature, writing, or language not covered in the regular course listings and intended particularly for the general liberal arts student. May be repeated for additional credit in a different field of study.

ENGL 340.course_description: A course that teaches practical, applicable, real-world writing skills and forms. The course may focus on grant writing, science writing, technical writing, writing for nonprofits, multimodal composing, writing for the web, blogging and digital writing, writing in the public sphere, advanced argument, rhetorical studies, literacy studies, or other composition studies, individually or in combination. Intended particularly for the general liberal arts student and/or English elective credits. May be repeated for additional credit in a different focus area.

ENGL 354.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of fiction. Includes extensive reading in contemporary fiction. Students revise and complete a series of short works or one longer work.

ENGL 355.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of poetry. Students write and critique poems, discuss poems in light of current issues, and practice selection and preparation of poems for publication.

ENGL 356.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of a creative writing genre such as the Novel, Graphic Fiction, Translation, or Screenwriting. May be repeated for additional credit.

ENGL 358.course_description: Intensive study of and practice with the techniques of the personal narrative essay. Includes attention to style, structure, audience, and critical thinking. Students complete three to four narrative essays and prepare them for publication when appropriate.

ENGL 359.course_description: A closely supervised practical experience in a professional setting for upper class English majors and minors. Internships may be taken by individual arrangement through the department with a local host company or agency, or as part of The Philadelphia Center, the New York Arts or the Washington Semester programs. At the discretion of the department, up to four credits may be applied toward the student’s major or minor requirements; otherwise, the credits (up to a total of eight) will constitute elective credits beyond the minimum required for a major or minor. The general guideline for each credit is 3 hours on the job per week for a fifteen-week semester.

ENGL 393.course_description: An independent, student-designed writing project culminating in a significant and complete body of creative or expository writing offered to students who have exhausted the regular offering of writing courses in the department. May be repeated for additional credit with a different project.

ENGL 401.course_description: This course is the culminating course for creative writers. Workshop participants focus their work according to genre interests; view creative work through the lens of literary criticism; prepare manuscripts for publication; and provide feedback to peer work in progress.

ENGL 100V.course_name: Introductory Themes in Literature: Empires of the World and Mind
ENGL 100V.course_description: Introductory Themes in Literature is a gateway to literature course designed to explore themes in British, American, and Anglophone literature through reading, discussion, and writing. The areas of exploration vary with individual instructors. Typical themes include magical realism, migrations and diasporas, heroes and monsters, faith and spirituality, pop culture and hip hop, race and justice, and ecojustice and the environment.

ENGL 110.course_description: Themed courses at the introductory level will focus on the exploration of a theme or topic in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms. The selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to write creatively and critically and to collaborate effectively in reading and writing communities. The courses will introduce students to literary genres, genre conventions, and literary concepts for close reading. Topics may include: Migration and Return in African Diaspora Literature; Magical Realism in Latinx Diaspora Literature; Apocalyptic Anxieties in Literature; Personal Essay; Rebooting the Classics; Marriage in the Modern Age; or Speak of the Devil. Students will engage in reflective and/or analytical writing (at least 10 pages, collectively, including drafts, free writing, reader responses, journaling etc.) to develop a deeper understanding of thoughts, experiences, and creations. Attention will be paid to the thesis, organization, and structure.

ENGL 130.course_description: Survey courses at the introductory level will focus on periods and movements in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms. The selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to write creatively and critically and collaborate effectively in reading and writing communities. The courses will introduce students to literary genres, genre conventions, and literary concepts for close reading. Topics may include: Film & Fiction; Rebooting the Classics; Peace & Justice in the Latin Hemispheres; Colonialism, Literature, and the Human Condition; Magical Worlds in Children’s Fiction; Love and Violence in Ancient Literature from Virgil to Dante. Students will engage in reflective and/or analytical writing (at least 10 pages, collectively, including drafts, free writing, reader responses, journaling etc.) to develop a deeper understanding of thoughts, experiences, and creations. Attention will be paid to the thesis, organization, and structure.

ENGL 160.course_description: Author courses at the introductory level will focus on the study of major works of authors and situate those works within a specific timeframe in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms. The selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to write creatively and critically and collaborate effectively in reading and writing communities. The courses will introduce students to literary genres, genre conventions, and literary concepts for close reading. Topics may include: J.R.R. Tolkien and Medieval Literature; Ernest Hemingway: Film & Fiction; The Poetics of Hip-Hop; Engaging the Graphic Novel; C.S. Lewis & the Liberal Arts; The African Novel; Stephen King: Trash or Talent. Students will engage in reflective and/or analytical writing (at least 10 pages, collectively, including drafts, free writing, reader responses, journaling etc.) to develop a deeper understanding of thoughts, experiences, and creations. Attention will be paid to the thesis, organization, and structure.

ENGL 210.course_description: Themed courses at the intermediate level will focus on the exploration of a theme or topic in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms, and the selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to incorporate research effectively and innovatively, write successfully across genres, and use tools of literary analysis to interpret course readings.The courses will examine genre conventions in works of literature and will offer a more in-depth study of literary concepts and critical theory for close reading. Courses that could be offered in Fall 2023 include Pilgrims & Pilgrimage; Peace & Justice in Young Adult Literature; Migration in Latinx Diaspora Literature; and The Girl in Fiction. In Spring 2024, course offerings could include Race & Justice in Young Adult Literature; Colonialism to Post-Independence: Africa & the Caribbean; and Environmental Humanities . Students will do two (2) or more significant academic writing assignments that total at least 20 pages, and at least one (1) of these is a thesis-driven assignment that integrates research and demonstrates information literacy. The writing process will include drafting and revising.

ENGL 220.course_description: This course follows the whole story of the English language, from its pre-history as a member of the Indo-European family of languages to a global language. The course focuses on philology, the linguistic tools for the study of English literature in its Old, Middle, and Modern forms. Additional areas of emphasis include varieties of English around the world ( and especially in the United States), and the relationship between the language and the history of those who use it, from the Norman Conquest to the impacts of computers and globalization.

ENGL 224.course_description: Literary theory is a set of approaches to interpreting not just literary works but texts of any kind: films, video games, speeches, buildings. This course will tour major schools of thought from Plato to the twenty-first century, such as formalism, structuralism, mimetic theory, deconstruction, psychoanalytic criticism, gender and sexuality studies, postcolonial criticism, race studies, ecocriticism, and disability theory. It will feature selected primary texts from theorists such as Jacques Derrida, Michel Foucault, René Girard, Adrienne Rich, Judith Butler, Edward Said, Chinua Achebe, Toni Morrison, and Wendell Berry. Class discussion and writing assignments will focus on using theoretical lenses to interpret texts of your choice. The course will be conducted as a seminar with several short papers and two longer ones.

ENGL 230.course_description: Survey courses at the intermediate level will focus on periods and movements in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms, and the selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to incorporate research effectively and innovatively, write successfully across genres, and use tools of literary analysis to interpret course readings. The courses will examine genre conventions in works of literature and will offer a more in-depth study of literary concepts and critical theory for close reading. Topics may include: Modern Global Literature; Western World Literature; The Making of American Literature; Dramatic Literature on Broadway; Survey of American Ethnic Literature; Bromantics to Brexit: A British Literature Survey; American Short Story Since 1900; Women Writers: Path Makers and Rule Breakers; How to Interpret Anything. Students will do two (2) or more significant academic writing assignments that total at least 20 pages, and at least one (1) of these is a thesis-driven assignment that integrates research and demonstrates information literacy. The writing process will include drafting and revising.

ENGL 248.course_description: An introduction to college-level study of literature. This course explores a variety of texts from different genres. The course is designed to increase students’ skill and confidence in reading literature (especially the close reading of poetry and prose), to practice the interpretation of texts through representative contemporary critical methods, and to enhance students’ enjoyment of reading, discussing, and writing about literature. Open to all students. It, or an equivalent experience, is required of English majors and minors, and language arts composite majors.

ENGL 260.course_description: Author courses at the intermediate level will focus on the study of major works of authors and situate those works within a specific timeframe in the development of the literature. The course will explore expressions of the human condition in literary forms, and the selected readings will equip students with the knowledge and skills to incorporate research effectively and innovatively, write successfully across genres, and use tools of literary analysis to interpret course readings. The courses will examine genre conventions in works of literature and will offer a more in-depth study of literary concepts and critical theory for close reading. Topics may include: Strange Pain: Listening to Women; US/Latino Writers of Today; Harry Potter & Virtue Ethics; Latin American Women Writers; Chinua Achebe: Revisiting the Heart of Darkness. Students will do two (2) or more significant academic writing assignments that total at least 20 pages, and at least one (1) of these is a thesis-driven assignment that integrates research and demonstrates information literacy. The writing process will include drafting and revising.

ENGL 310.course_description: A study of early forms of literature in Medieval England. Masterpieces like Beowulf, and the works of authors as J.R.R. Tolkien, Chaucer, etc. will be studied.

ENGL 311.course_description: An thematic, historical, and stylistic examination of the works of William Shakespeare and its impact on the development of English literature. Instructors choose the specific area of study: tragedies, histories, comedies etc.

ENGL 313.course_description: A study of the historical trajectoties and global influences of Shakespeare’s works in different cultures.

ENGL 315.course_name: 17th, 18th and Early 19th Century British and American Literature
ENGL 315.course_description: A study of the early works of English literature from the 17th century to the 19th in British and American literature.

ENGL 330.course_description: A broad survey of themes or topics in different periods, histories, and cultures in African/Caribbean literature, with emphasis on modernism/postmodernism, colonialism/postcolonialism, diaspora/return.

ENGL 331.course_description: A broad survey of the themes/topics in different periods, histories, and cultural values in Latinx literature, with emphasis on tpics as cultral diference and integration, language and identity, migration etc.

ENGL 335.course_description: A broad survey of themes/topics in different periods, histories, and cultural values in African American literature, with emphasis on topics like slavery, emancipation, Harlem Renaissance, the Civil Rights Movement etc.

ENGL 337.course_description: A broad survey of themes or topics in different periods, histories, and cultural values in Asian American literature, with emphasis on topics like land dispossession and devastation, identity crisis and cultural integration, etc.

ENGL 370.course_description: A study of major figures and movements in English and American literature with advanced literary study, genres (including Children’s and Young Adult literature), with choice of author/text reflecting period of study.

ENGL 372.course_description: A survey of the masterpieces in British literature. Instructor chooses period of study.

ENGL 374.course_description: A survey of the masterpieces in American literature. Instructor chooses period of study.

ENGL 400.course_description: This course will culminate in a research essay of 15-20 pages that demonstrates the ability to use the methods and theoretical tools of literary studies; the topic of research, both the text(s) to be interpreted and the theoretical lenses to be used for analysis, will be entirely open to student choice and may include film, TV, or newer media. Course content will focus on examples of the application of literary theories and the use of tools of literary research. The course will take a workshop approach in part, so that students would do some workshopping of their final project and maybe other projects, like different theoretical approaches to the same text.

ENGL 380.course_description: A study of and experience in applying methods of teaching grammar, discussion, literature, and composition in the secondary school.

ENGL 381.course_name: Teaching of English in the Secondary Schools Clinical Experience

ENGL 290.course_description: An individual research project, by arrangement with a professor, investigating some topic in depth and culminating in a paper that demonstrates literary scholarship and independent thought. May be repeated for additional credit, with a different project.

ENGL 390.course_description: An individual research project, by arrangement with a professor, investigating some topic in depth and culminating in a paper that demonstrates literary scholarship and independent thought. May be repeated for additional credit, with a different project.

ENGL 490.course_description: An individual research project, by arrangement with a professor, investigating some topic in depth and culminating in a paper that demonstrates literary scholarship and independent thought. May be repeated for additional credit, with a different project.

ENGS 070.course_name: Preparation for the Engineering Profession I
ENGS 070.course_description: This seminar is intended for second year engineering students. The focus of the course will be on preparation for obtaining an internship and personal conduct in a professional environment. Topics will include resume and cover letter preparation, interview skills, networking, engineering ethics, cultural competencies in a global workplace, and other topics in engineering practice. Seminars will also provide students the opportunity to discuss state of the art engineering advances with speakers actively engaged in the field.

ENGS 080.course_name: Preparation for the Engineering Profession II
ENGS 080.course_description: This seminar is intended for third year engineering students. This course builds on the content of Engs 070 to further prepare students to enter the engineering profession or graduate school. Topics will include leadership, project management, graduate school and alternate career paths, engineering ethics, cultural competencies for success, and other topics in engineering practice. Seminars will also provide students additional opportunities to discuss state of the art engineering advances with speakers actively engaged in the field.

ENGS 100.course_description: This course introduces students to the basic principles of engineering and the various disciplines that constitute the field. Major engineering accomplishments are studied from historical, political, artistic and economic viewpoints. Students work in teams to solve engineering design problems and undertake laboratory investigations. Foundations of engineering science including force equilibrium, concepts of stress and strain, Ohm’s Law, and Kirchhoff’s Voltage and Current Laws are studied.

ENGS 100L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

ENGS 122.course_description: An introduction to the science and engineering of materials with an emphasis on application to engineering design. Topics will include structure-processing-property relationships in materials, atomic bonding, crystal structure, phase diagrams, control of deformation in metals, a survey of common engineering materials and their properties, and materials selection for engineering design.

ENGS 150.course_description: An introduction to chemical engineering calculations, emphasizing the conservation of mass and energy. Systems studied will include batch and continuous processes, and separation processes. Concepts of steady-state and transient balances will be used in process analysis.

ENGS 170.course_description: An introduction to computer aided design. Students will learn to use a solid modeling design system for the purpose of creating their own designs. Design methods and techniques will be studied through development of increasingly complex devices. Each student is expected to design a device of their own choosing.

ENGS 170L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

ENGS 195.course_description: A course offered in response to student and instructor interest. Topics are not generally covered in the regular course listings. Course may be taken multiple times if topics are different.

ENGS 210.course_description: This course introduces students to the fundamental computer programming concepts, principles, and methods necessary for solving engineering problems encountered in engineering courses, industry, and research. Students are exposed to basic problem solving and programming techniques, fundamental algorithms and data structures, and use of programming logic in solving engineering problems. Students are expected to complete assignments in a collaborative learning environment.

BIOL 332.course_description: A course that extensively studies the evolutionary adaptations of anatomy across several taxa of animals. The course is solely laboratory dissections of many aquatic and terrestrial vertebrates. An excellent preparatory for students interested in any career within the Health Professions or Life Sciences.

BIOL 332L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 335.course_description: In this course, students will explore how the biochemistry of the brain influences nervous system function, specifically in relationship to motor and cognitive processes. Students will initially be introduced to fundamental aspects of neuroscience and biochemistry in a traditional lecture format. After this introduction, students will explore the relationship between altered neurochemical activity and disease states using a case study approach. In the lab, students will be introduced to several neurochemistry techniques and will then be asked to use these tools to complete a novel neurochemistry research project. The

BIOL 335L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 340.course_description: An in-depth study of specialized topics in botany such as plant anatomy, plant breeding systems, plant molecular systematics, and ecophysiology of plants.

BIOL 340L.course_name: Advanced Topics in Plant Biology Laboratory
BIOL 340L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 341.course_description: This course introduces the principles of virology including the molecular biology of viral replication, virus-host cell interactions, immune response to infection, pathogenesis, control strategies (i.e., vaccines), virus-based medical therapies, epidemiology of emerging viruses, and the history of pandemics.

BIOL 343.course_description: A study of the biology, evolutionary relationships and identification of selected families of vascular plants, and the principles of plant classification. The laboratory will involve field work and concentrate on the local flora. Additional out-of-class hours are required.

BIOL 343L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 348.course_description: An advanced study of cell structure, function and regulation of eukaryotic cells. The goal of this course is for students to learn and understand cellular/molecular mechanisms that are essential in the maintenance of cellular homeostasis. The specific topics include cell membrane, cell organelles, cytoskeleton, extracellular matrix and cell cycle. The gene structure and function is also explored.

BIOL 349.course_description: The laboratory course employs an investigative project approach and introduces students to the scientific literature, “research proposal” writing, and latest technologies used to investigate cellular function. The experiments focus on the cancer cell as a model and employ such techniques as cell culture, assays measuring cell proliferation and apoptosis, RNA isolation and microarray analysis, immunocytochemistry, and finally, protein analysis through gel electrophoresis and Western blotting. Students may take

BIOL 355.course_description: A study of the processes involved in the development of animal embryos, including regeneration and metamorphosis. The course integrates the descriptive, comparative and molecular approaches to the study of development.

BIOL 355L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 356.course_description: A comprehensive overview of genetics from its classical beginnings, including Mendelian genetics, linkage, chromosomal aberrations and extranuclear inheritance to modern molecular genetics. After a thorough grounding, topical subjects are covered in the last part of the semester, and have included cancer genetics, genetics of behavior, and population genetics.

BIOL 357.course_description: Designed to introduce the student to the experimental basis of lecture topics. Investigations include the purification and analysis of DNA, generation and sequencing of recombinant DNA molecules, and Drosophila and bacterial genetics.

BIOL 366.course_description: An advanced course which examines the role of gene structure, function, and regulation at the molecular level to explain biological processes. Topics include basic processes such as DNA replication, recombination, and regulation of gene expression, as well as an emphasis on experimental design and techniques. The laboratory component of the course uses a project approach to introduce experimental design and molecular biological methods as students clone and characterize a gene.

BIOL 366L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 370.course_description: An investigation-based study of vertebrate and invertebrate behavior from an evolutionary perspective. Topics include proximate behavioral mechanisms (genetic, developmental and neurological) and ultimate consequences (evolution, ecology and sociology).

BIOL 370L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 374.course_description: The course is an introduction to the identification, structure, life cycle, ecology and behavior of insects. Field aspects will be stressed. Additional out-of-class hours required.

BIOL 374L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 380.course_description: A concentrated study of a variety of organisms in their natural habitats. Normally requires field studies or camping trips as long as two to three weeks in duration. In addition study projects and/or papers will be expected. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

BIOL 380L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 390.course_description: A special course to allow students to study an area of biology not included in the regular curriculum or an in-depth study of a selected biological topic.

BIOL 395.course_description: This course may be a lecture or laboratory on a topic in biology related to special interests of the faculty or to significant current developments in the field.

BIOL 395L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 421.course_description: A study of special topics concerning the process of evolution and its mechanisms involving both micro and macro evolution. Each year a different special topic is explored. Past examples include evolutionary molecular biology and speciation.

BIOL 421L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 422.course_description: The biology of selected invertebrate animals will be studied with emphasis on their functional morphology, ecology and behavior. Three hours of lecture per week, plus additional out-of-class hours.

BIOL 422L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 432.course_description: Vertebrate examples are used to investigate a broad range of biological topics including evolution, speciation, historical and modern zoogeography, energetics, behavior, ecology and conservation. Laboratory includes both laboratory exercises and field trips that focus on the taxonomy, external morphology, natural history and field identification of local vertebrates. Additional out-of-class hours required.

BIOL 432L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 442.course_description: An in-depth examination of comparative aspects of animal physiology such as cardiovascular systems, renal physiology, endocrinology, immunology, or environmental physiology. Additional out-of-class hours required.

BIOL 442L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

BIOL 490.course_description: This course is designed to give students majoring in biology a chance to do research in an area in which they have a special interest. Students are expected to attend weekly seminars. Requires formal application and permission of the instructor with whom the student will work.

BIOL 490R.course_description: This course is designed to give students majoring in biology a chance to do research in an area in which they have a special interest. Students are expected to attend weekly seminars. Requires formal application and permission of the instructor with whom the student will work.

BIOL 493.course_description: Course provides opportunity for a junior or senior biology major to engage in an independent study project in an area in which the student has special interest.

BIOL 495.course_description: A special course, sometimes taught as a seminar, which deals with a specific area of biology at an advanced level. Past topics have included environmental genetic theory, the biology of sex, the heart and kidney, cancer biology, ecology of plant-animal interactions, and cholesterol biology.

BIOL 499.course_description: An opportunity to gain practical experience in the work place. Requires formal application and permission of the department chairperson.

BUS 150.course_description: This course will introduce students to the various functions of business – finance, marketing, operations, human resources, and accounting. It will examine how they relate to and complement each other as well as various types of businesses – for profit, social enterprise and non-profit. In addition, it will introduce students to ways of thinking about their own personal development as it relates to calling and careers in business organizations. The course includes applied aspects which could include simulations, organization visits and panel discussions. Reserved for first-year students or students pursuing a major or minor in business. Students who are exploring a minor starting in their junior year may be exempted from this course.

BUS 195.course_description: A lecture or seminar class in a special topic of business for majors and non-majors in business.

BUS 222.course_description: Study of modern managerial principles and processes as usually associated with business (but which principles also apply to the management of non-profit organizations such as churches, schools, etc.) through an examination of the functions of planning, organizing, leadership and controlling. Current problems facing businesses are reviewed. Changing patterns of management are discussed. Students may take

BUS 223.course_description: This course focuses on vocational discernment, self awareness and exploration of possible career paths. Students will engage with a variety of alumni and professionals as they learn and discern how their interests and abilities may fit accounting, economics, finance, marketing and other roles. They will participate in panels, assessments, resume reviews, mock interviews and structured networking.

BUS 295.course_description: A lecture or seminar class in a special topic of business for majors and non-majors in business.

BUS 331.course_description: This course develops decision-making skills in the context of managing the marketing function in all types of organizations. This project-based course includes team assignment to a company marketing opportunity. Simulations and case studies describing actual marketing problems provide an opportunity for the student to develop an appreciation for the types of problems which exist in the real world of marketing; and to develop the skills of analysis and decision-making necessary for success in marketing and other areas of organizations. Topics include marketing opportunity analysis, market segmentation, product policy, promotion, channels of distribution, pricing policy, and the analysis of complete marketing programs.

BUS 341.course_description: A survey of business law, stressing contracts and including an introduction to sales, agency, negotiable instruments, and partnerships and corporations.

BUS 351.course_description: This course will provide an introduction to the field of organizational behavior (“OB”). OB examines how individuals, groups, and structure impact behavior within an organization. Specifically, it focuses on how both individual differences (e.g., personality, values) and the environment (e.g., culture, leadership style, type of group) motivate and constrain individual behavior in an organization such as motivation and commitment. An understanding of OB can help to build organizations that better support employees, build commitment and improve performance just to name a few.

BUS 352.course_description: The analytical and applied approach to human resources management for potential human resource professionals, line management, or employees. Traditional personnel and labor relations topics are presented such as the legal environment for management of employees, job analysis, recruiting and selection of employees, performance evaluation, discipline, and labor negotiation.

BUS 356.course_description: The study of practices usually associated with business, but applicable to other organizations, that create environmentally sustainable outcomes.

BUS 358.course_description: This interdisciplinary course explores the culture, politics, and economy of the British along with their values and attitudes toward business. Special attention is paid to unique forms of management and business organizations. This class utilizes an experiential-based learning environment that includes seminars with leaders of business, labor, and government; company visits; and numerous cultural activities that are conducted in London and in various other locations in England.

BUS 361.course_description: This course examines the management of the conversion process – converting raw materials, land, labor, capital, and management inputs into desired outputs of goods and services. This will include the study of traditional approaches as well as new contributions from just-in-time practices, constraint theory, total quality management, and statistical process control. The analysis of operational decisions will include strategic, productivity, and ethical considerations.

BUS 371.course_description: This course examines financial decision making within the context of public corporations. The concepts of risk, rates of return, time value of money, valuation, and stewardship are utilized to analyze financial decisions involving capital budgeting and capital structure. The analysis of these decisions will include both financial and ethical considerations.

BUS 381.course_description: This course is designed to build skills for the formulation and implementation of strategy. In order to build and sustain competitive advantage, all areas of the organization need to be included. As such, students will draw on the foundational knowledge they have built in their prior courses while they approach topics including industry analysis, strategic analysis of firm resources/capabilities, as well as the crafting and implementation of strategy. Business-level, corporate-level, and global strategy will also be discussed.

BUS 382.course_description: This course is designed to help students understand the basic definitions, principles and functions of various investment products. Students will be exposed to the various types of risks associated with investment as well as their correlation to expected investment returns. Throughout the course we will apply the tools of risk analysis to contemporary issues affecting multiple investment options. After taking this course students will better understand and relate to the investment topics and issues that are relevant to everyday life.

BUS 384.course_description: The majority of today’s most successful companies are investing in the development of their analytical capabilities. They believe that these capabilities are required to compete in today’s marketplace. This has driven the demand for staff who understand the fundamentals of business analytics. This is true in every key function and department. This demand for staff who are familiar with the fundamentals of business analytics exceeds the supply. Virtually everyone hired by these companies today is expected to bring a higher level of analytic skill and knowledge to the job than was expected of their predecessors. This course will give students a broad exposure to modern business analytics. It will familiarize students with the ways these analytics are applied by a variety of companies in a variety of industries. It will provide students with an understanding of how analytics are used in a variety of functions within these companies. It will help students understand how analytics creates value for these companies.

BUS 390.course_description: The objective of this course is to help students 1) integrate theory and practice, 2) enhance their self-awareness and social-awareness competencies, and 3) seek their mission in the world. The course is a customized and highly reflective experience involving the professor, the student, and the placement supervisor. Enrollment in the class is dependent upon students finding their own internship placements by working with the

BUS 395.course_description: A lecture or seminar in a special topic in advanced business.

BUS 401.course_description: This seminar in management is intended to challenge participants to evaluate several aspects of management more thoroughly than possible in a traditional classroom setting. Students will work closely with the professor and others to read, evaluate, and discuss topics of critical importance to successful leadership in organizations. Professors may emphasize a management topic of particular interest to them and their professional study. Common components may include: study of classic management readings and materials; Christianity and leadership; vocation and calling as applied to management; personal finance; business ethics; global business; and a written analysis of case studies and other topics. A significant research paper may be required. Completion of major requirements is highly recommended prior to this course. Students may take

BUS 490.course_description: Independent studies in advanced business under the supervision of a designated staff member. Advanced standing in the department is highly recommended prior to this course.

BUS 495.course_description: A lecture or seminar in a special topic in advanced business. For example, Total Quality Management and Finance Seminar have recently been offered under this number. Permission of instructor is required.

CHEM 101.course_description: This course presents selected chemical concepts at an introductory level for students who are not majoring in one of the sciences. Topics include atomic, ionic and molecular properties, bonding, balanced equations, acids and bases, solutions, simple organic structures, polymers, and nuclear chemistry. Laboratory activities support concepts presented in lecture.

CHEM 101L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

CHEM 102A.course_name: Matter and Energy Pre-K through 3rd Grades
CHEM 102A.course_description: Matter and Energy Pre-K to 3rd Grade is a half-semester course designed for those seeking Pre-K - 3rd grade elementary certification. It will help satisfy the natural science laboratory general education requirements for elementary education teacher candidates. The course will cover content outlined in the Michigan K-12 Science Standards as well as the Michigan Department of Education (MDE) Standards for the Preparation of Teachers of Early Childhood (Pre-K) and Lower Elementary in an integrated lecture/lab, inquiry-based format. This course will primarily include content from physical science and earth/space science. Teacher candidates will leave this course with the ability to make sound curricular choices for 3-Dimensional science learning, identify phenomena to engage students in content, and lead lessons that involve sense-making, arguing with evidence, developing and improving science investigations, analyzing results, and communicating conclusions. Teacher candidates will also experience MDE Core Teaching Practices that make science learning equitable and accessible for all.

CHEM 102B.course_description: Matter and Energy 3rd through 6th Grades is a half-semester course designed for those seeking 3rd - 6th grade elementary certification. It will help satisfy the natural science laboratory general education requirements for elementary education teacher candidates. The course will cover content outlined in the Michigan K-12 Science Standards as well as the Michigan Department of Education (MDE) Standards for the Preparation of Teachers of Upper Elementary (3-6) in an integrated lecture/lab, inquiry-based format. This course will primarily include content from physical science and earth/space science. Teacher candidates will leave this course with the ability to make sound curricular choices for 3-Dimensional science learning, identify phenomena to engage students in content, and lead lessons that involve sense-making, arguing with evidence, developing and improving science investigations, analyzing results, and communicating conclusions. Teacher candidates will also experience MDE Core Teaching Practices that make science learning equitable and accessible for all.

CHEM 103.course_description: This course will equip students with analytic and conceptual skills in general, organic, and biological chemistry as they relate to human health and health care. It is particularly focused on the basic chemistry needed by students seeking to enter professional programs in nursing and in a few allied health fields. This course is also suitable for the non-science major student as partial fulfillment of the mathematics and natural science general education requirement. This course does not count toward a major in biochemistry/molecular biology, biology, or chemistry. One year of high school chemistry is highly recommended prior to this course.

CHEM 103L.course_description: This is the laboratory that accompanies

CHEM 122.course_description: This course begins with a three-day field and laboratory research experience in the Macatawa Watershed. Students will address issues of water quality that have plagued Lake Macatawa for over a century. The research findings are essential for understanding the impact of

CHEM 125.course_description: This is the first course in a two-semester sequence of introductory chemistry that is for all students who wish to major in science. Topics include stoichiometry, states of matter, atomic structure, periodicity, chemical bonding, and geometry of molecules. Students with strong high school preparation should consider

CHEM 125D.course_description: This is the discussion that accompanies

CHEM 126.course_description: This is the second in a two-semester sequence of introductory chemistry that is for all students who wish to major in science. Topics include chemical energy, equilibria, kinetics, acids and bases, and chemical reaction types.

CHEM 126D.course_description: This is the discussion that accompanies

CHEM 127.course_description: This course provides an introduction to chemical techniques and laboratory procedures. Topics include qualitative analysis, gas laws, colorimetry, spectroscopy, colligative properties, computational modeling and computerized data collection and analysis. Laboratory, one 3-hour session per week (42 lab hours).

CHEM 221.course_description: The basic principles of organic chemistry are introduced through studies of the structures and reactions of carbon compounds. The mechanistic treatment of aliphatic and aromatic chemistry is stressed.

CHEM 255.course_description: This laboratory course stresses modern techniques for analyses of organic compounds and studies of the mechanisms of organic reactions. Infrared spectral analyses and chromatographic separations are introduced. Laboratory, one 5-hour session per week (84 lab hours).

CHEM 255D.course_description: This is the discussion that accompanies

CHEM 295.course_description: A lecture and/or laboratory course in a chemical area of current interest.

CHEM 311.course_description: The biochemistry of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, enzymes and coenzymes is discussed with an emphasis on the structure/function properties of biomolecules.

CHEM 311D.course_description: This is the optional discussion that accompanies
